CEDD0E10BD7B497592D3735669D04114.description: Collaborate with others to create interdisciplinary work that addresses issues of social justice and/or other topics of interest to youth (e.g., relationships, body image, racism, sustainability).

9707847D2877419380151E9251F3304C.description: Examine and discuss various interdisciplinary arts expressions (i.e., using two or more disciplines in the work).

2CB2A0E996A04C3C9B1A807570796BB4.description: Examine and respond to the work of artists who incorporate more than one art form in their work (e.g., combining poetry and music).

EE748804EC54461390EBA82F7C56FC71.description: Describe the role of new technology in the creation and marketing of contemporary arts (e.g., innovative graphics programs, music editing software, social networking sites).

B12BF206DA4F49C48776E8B6568E492A.description: Ask questions to initiate and develop inquiry into artists who use technology and incorporate technology into their work.

C42515F54E43490CBF86F27601BCE767.description: Demonstrate understanding of how contemporary artists use and incorporate new technology into their work.

E8493A35480B4E778F8367C95A52AEFB.description: Create a plan to share the research findings with younger and older students and community members where possible (e.g., create a dance, drama, music performance, or visual installation).

886DFF90E971486C8929A36BACDFC93D.description: Investigate the work of artists that reflects a concern with historical events including Treaties and the impacts of colonization such as residential schools, racism, and marginalization.

8AFE5E7790D54C708F50CA4EF2BED992.description: Identify social factors that influence First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artists, their work, and careers (e.g., typecasting of actors, limited access to venues and markets).

0F18ECB512F249418E0503B63BFF0D7F.description: Research First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artists who use their art work to explore and comment on social issues (e.g., Susan Aglukark, Edward Poitras).

0A899AAE465545A5A238A7A4376A64D2.description: Analyze the influence of social issues on the work of contemporary First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artists, and share results.

B0A65C985141432D8338353745B014F5.description: Analyze and comment on the effectiveness of using the arts as a vehicle for social change.

763850EAD5974E268DED02D0C6CFB57F.description: Present research findings, using technology where appropriate, on Canadian visual and performing artists whose work includes social commentary.

88F15FAB7751497A8F0BDECFFAFDD1F2.description: Research independently, using the Internet and other sources, the work of visual and performing artists who address social issues

C729563F0999480A864AC89935305B3E.description: Research and share insights about arts expressions that incorporate social commentary.

D121D402B00B4E578C5E17E50D2F4FE4.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) - Children will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and understand the connection between the arts and human experience.

A85469A1E9E640F8999A1ED310886DF2.description: Examine, discuss, and participate in cultural/historical studies from diverse cultural perspectives (e.g., learn heritage social dances, play Latin music, or create Indonesian shadow puppets).

53BCC81E33B0494EA71EBD4F423D569F.description: Examine global change and its influence on today’s arts expressions.

30E7B848498F45E0BD11C2F205F65F63.description: Describe how diverse worldviews may be represented in the arts.

2A596606CB85417591B0D8BBA8A9F8DB.description: Discuss and describe the meaning of worldview

53BDF1BD8A8F46068A52F0637EE76608.description: Investigate and identify how arts expressions can reflect diverse worldviews.

BF87817324224285A7AEDAF74185E6A3.description: Describe, analyze, and interpret the work (dance, drama, music, visual, film) of a variety of artists whose work incorporates social commentary.

987345E4A48A4CE79AD5817C041415DF.description: Conduct inquiry into social justice and diversity issues in the arts including stereotyping and bias (e.g., stereotyping of male dancers, or the lack of women or First Nations artists represented in history of the arts books).

6B25D458868046BB959BA94227FD020D.description: Reflect on and analyze the intentions, development, and interpretations of own and peers’ arts expressions in relation to social contexts (e.g., Is the work influenced by pop culture or local community issues?).

1BD0D091D9424873A36D39627AE47AB2.description: Investigate and identify ways that today’s arts expressions often reflect concern for social issues.

7039FAC5419F4D5B9C5BA70A6F25AF7C.description: Create own work (e.g., visual or performing arts) in response to a professional arts expression, and describe how own work is inspired or influenced by the original work.

7B7426AEB1AE4E7AA6478FD2160F2CD8.description: Respond to arts expressions using one or more approaches such as those described in online curriculum support materials entitled “Responding to Arts Expressions”

55E84D7474BD4F7EB92311D654CBA98B.description: Analyze and discuss how dance, drama, music, visual and interdisciplinary arts are expressions of individual or collective perspectives.

5483FF79EB7E4EBEBC704B9FE54851A3.description: Describe, analyze, and interpret arts expressions of personal interest.

533E3DF804424C03B541B8E87F29D6AE.description: Respond to professional dance, drama, music, and visual art works through the creation of own arts expressions.

F85FDD288CEA4D538C32AD8F39D6D5B7.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) - Children will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry

93B816E6F3274703A61BBB02AD34E194.description: Explain original intent, why choices were made, how problems were solved, and how work might be refined or extended.

76F58596FF2A4E3499BDE863185085ED.description: Take risks by working with innovative ideas, unfamiliar styles, or media.

2D6F3E7E35E647D6A9502B435DC4E1D0.description: Keep an ongoing record of ideas and works in progress for own visual art expressions (e.g., journals, blog, online diary, or portfolio)

0A5D413D78C3438E87511C63E1466FE7.description: Generate and develop ideas from a variety of sources that are of interest or personal significance.

9888AD34ECD24CFF8F8B2224786D9FD0.description: Explore and expand upon an idea to achieve more depth of meaning and expression.

1A4278BA8E134825B2E7DCB521424C3C.description: Solve visual art problems using a variety of processes and media.

E4EA9C30BEE946238441C7F3C035594C.description: Examine how artists use symbols and imagery to communicate meaning, and apply this understanding in own work.

F4B2D69CD62C471EB25A9961F4F07C6B.description: Use symbols and other images to develop and represent ideas

2829DEAB5CB34F25BF7EE87303706266.description: Describe how emphasis controls the sequence in which parts or images are noticed, and indicates their relative importance.

E803D7BD836B462E8E83EC0C16E69CFE.description: Analyze and discuss how images and materials work together to express ideas in a work of art.

5492E3954A1E496F91102765F353FE94.description: Examine how visual weight is created through the use of size, colour, contour, contrast, texture, value, position, and so on.

7F2AA64A80104E4A8436A4036810BC57.description: Investigate the effects of using more or less contrast.

64C7D03ECBA34A328A37F164F7FBEB49.description: Create three-dimensional and two-dimensional art works, and use knowledge of art elements and design principles to enhance the work.

E965BAD0277346959B5EAD6B6ED85DAC.description: Select visual art forms (e.g., print-making, installations, animation) to express ideas about social issues.

149E30B1F77148078D2D8E206B06A355.description: Select and use appropriate forms, technologies, images, and art-making processes to express student perspectives on social issues.

1E4A1D4707FC49409CE9E3CEACF509CE.description: Demonstrate co-ordination and skills for using appropriate tools, materials, and techniques to express ideas visually.

0B68D71A7F234878958D23E8DFF1FF51.description: Use inquiry in visual art to express student perspectives on social issues (e.g., poverty, racism, homophobia, sustainability): • Generate key questions to guide inquiry (e.g., How could we represent through visual art the devastating effects of poverty or racism?), Collaborate with other students to develop a plan to guide inquiry. and Collaborate with other students to determine how to document the creative process.

23FC56FB55A647DBB17B7B21BABF204E.description: Create visual art works that express student perspectives on social issues (e.g., poverty, racism, homophobia, sustainability).

F5BB59B85BF642F795A3AB6C71EA8CCB.description: Extend understanding and use of traditional and nontraditional notational systems in representing sounds/music.

87B6AD60E89D49B990A106CD7D78360E.description: Describe how compositions are personal expressions of own sound/music ideas.

1E5FD40F4D36466597E4285FBFD4DDBF.description: Keep an ongoing record of ideas for own sound/music expressions (e.g., journals, audio tapes, video, blog, or web diary).

95556CECCD9046A4AE105A5823D4822D.description: Generate and develop music ideas from a variety of sources regarding social issues of interest to students.

2E8CE0406B744F1EA69142D75F2A3580.description: Explore and expand upon a musical idea to achieve more depth of meaning and expression.

76CD8DF1CD3F4292ADC55D2752CE9AAA.description: Determine appropriate sound sources, forms, and processes for creating music expression.

14B488C4726E470DBABBA84F711FC0AF.description: Make interpretive decisions, demonstrating understanding of a variety of ways in which music concepts can be applied (e.g., tempo, dynamics, articulation, tone colour).

CF1FE853C366451F86C70C03E9751D42.description: Create and perform own music compositions, improvisations, or song lyrics in response to a social issue of importance to students.

523F92B99B244F5397C7EA6A77027276.description: Examine the intentions, development, and interpretations of own and others’ music expressions in relation to social issues (e.g., antiwar songs, music with environmental messages, hip hop songs that promote positive life choices).

5E8C6051ACA345D18CFC87708E0C61D2.description: Demonstrate knowledge of how the elements and principles are used to create form and structure in music.

38C6ADDFF279428A87D37B75D1CD71E0.description: Critically examine the connections between the elements of music and principles of composition in own compositions and other music

5B53DE1CF39D47B8BC12162E5D1B78C6.description: Use inquiry in music to extend understanding of the elements of music and principles of composition: Pose questions to guide inquiry into how elements of music can be manipulated and structured to create balance and unity (e.g., What are the rhythmic and melodic possibilities/limitations with this instrument? What different timbres are possible with this instrument? What textures can be created by combining or layering a variety of vocal or instrumental sounds?), Conduct a collaborative inquiry and experiment with voice and instruments to explore inquiry questions about musical structure (e.g., In what ways could we rearrange these motifs or phrases in different sequences?), Collaborate with peers to document the inquiry process (e.g., traditional and/or invented notation, audio or video recording).

ABE7931AF6F1452195611B7CDA768D46.description: Investigate and make choices about musical structures in sound composition.

734FB09C91B3416D9418610B737658BF.description: Prepare, rehearse, present, and evaluate individual and group performances of contrasting styles of music.

758418DA7D5D404189DC0AA02BA5377E.description: Use the Internet and other sources to research and discuss composers who work in contrasting styles.

619F8EAFBF374E8C8E4FD037A37A04A5.description: Create composed and improvised melodic and rhythmic ostinati to accompany singing and playing.

F826A5A0C8AF4B649D764DF22931B25B.description: Investigate ways that silence can be used in improvisation and music composition.

A9FC3518542D48E5A3D14C1D4D6710D2.description: Create and improvise with an instrument paying attention to sound quality and intonation.

E15E2CADDC4847ED84EDB904FA80EB84.description: Improvise simple pieces around a given structure

4F64812621DC4BF89600462713F312C0.description: Examine and apply the technique of vocal improvisation in song and speech.

67DF8BB2FE224489A4B90B17C95306BA.description: Improvise, compose, and perform (e.g., with voice, instruments, and technologies) a selection of pieces in contrasting styles.

4F50FCC072B945F481F19D40D985A816.description: Analyze and describe the effectiveness of own drama to convey perspectives.

A7C6EAE53A0B4E219AB387A5F4594BDC.description: Demonstrate awareness of how to use language and negotiate the use of drama strategies to achieve dramatic purpose.

3F50CB19F97F4276A06FB91A0F1A651C.description: Use inquiry in drama to investigate topics of importance to students (e.g., issues of concern to youth or recent news items): Collaborate with other students to explore compelling questions through drama (What if a new law was passed that ...?), Brainstorm and negotiate with other students to determine how fictional situations and dramatic episodes might be explored, Collaborate on the development and refinement of several drama episodes or collective creation to address the selected issue, Recognize how research contributes to the authenticity and significance of the drama work and Contribute to the creation of a plan to document the creative process (e.g., reflective journal entries, video, photography, blog, or web-based diary).

96CBF7866FC7486BA4B8DBB44C23A739.description: Analyze and discuss how drama may be used to explore perspectives on social issues and promote understanding of topics of personal significance.

5C20D10C3D934C6ABF529AC6E23B3C19.description: Express student perspectives on social issues (e.g., poverty, racism, homophobia, sustainability, gangs) in drama and/or collective creation.

84004A3A5527403BA4F97AFC6748B77E.description: Analyze the use of movement, and the use of space and time in own work.

72D96D7C0E214A0D8FA0BE52E2FE686F.description: Demonstrate imagination when creating imaginary places and situations in own drama work.

EE677B96A54E4E40A90090D9E158E085.description: Consider and analyze how set, costumes, lighting, and sound/ music design can be manipulated to achieve different effects in own work.

8AA3D11BD2F14630B087B904A80CBF1B.description: Analyze how each character’s actions and the consequences of those actions affect the progression of the drama.

45F7061B791349C684B5A2F9528094E8.description: Identify how theatrical elements (e.g., story, role or character, technical design) can be manipulated to achieve a creative purpose and consider how such elements relate to own drama work.

4A1F0752BCD54D3A821DE83F1E12E764.description: Investigate how theatrical elements (e.g., story, character, design, space) are combined to achieve dramatic purpose.

EC57395B67434C9596CF8F943310A527.description: Examine how contrasts among characters function within the drama.

4E009882E1ED401B80AA76EADA2891C8.description: Reflect on sources and functions of tension expressed in relationships among roles or characters portrayed.

3E55ED63CE884833A55F0B3114A6CD4A.description: Demonstrate awareness of how focus is maintained and shifts during pair, small, and whole group drama work.

09AD1208B414419DB208BFADB2A80E41.description: Describe how focus, tension, and contrast function within the drama.

ACC8B2687D9F495CB573F6527DEB3427.description: Describe own roles and specific contributions to the collective drama work.

C18E5483394E45E1B5581313C667EF02.description: Demonstrate confidence and curiosity when assuming different kinds of roles in drama work.

5B10AF6CCF59451C9CB000559F566BDB.description: Sustain belief in own roles and in the roles assumed by others for extended periods of time.

0EB0B90F914540288668B42D44908E17.description: Demonstrate how dramatic characters interact in relationships within the drama and/or collective creation

6ED75230E6024BE9957FBC15DF9455B6.description: Encourage peers to extend bodies’ range of movement, strength, and balance with attention paid to correct alignment and clarity of action.

3C28140E825940D4B0D8F174D13239CF.description: Record dance phrases (e.g., notation or video) to further explore and reconstruct movements.

F3F65E57166A4468A01F8354069DEA21.description: Improvise and collaborate to refine movements and develop the choreography.

DF31227DB4544932B15B827AE4672BD4.description: Contribute to group discussions regarding possible structures or form for the dance (e.g., ABA, ABACA, narrative).

1DB8C92199D24B34A187435BD0343CF8.description: Draw on own imagination and ideas, and strengths of other dancers, when choreographing dance section.

EF87ED35338A469BBE273F25AD9ED3B8.description: Encourage peers to explore and contribute movement phrases to group choreography.

D41732820D964FA1B62CAE82E7F443C6.description: Demonstrate leadership and collaborative skills in the creation of one section of a group choreography.

4D5A8F4CFB674186859E8C13203E35D9.description: Choreograph one section of group choreography.

27D0036CED68483196AFB50BDF65BBD1.description: Perform self-created and collaboratively-created sequences of movements with smooth transitions (see grade 8 physical education curriculum outcome 8.9) during warm-ups and dance compositions.

1B511B5C3DDD41E4A958158C613E4EB2.description: Sequence and develop movements to express and communicate ideas.

2F41E723DE5A4542B98ADAC83722DD6F.description: Investigate expressive ways of using dynamics, rhythm, spatial design, focus, relationships, transitions, and contrast.

2322C0A2A77B41F0AB50BC697911F5C3.description: Use body and actions in innovative ways to develop sequences and ideas.

91DE87B0C9DF4060ADC2713221C7E298.description: Order the movements (sequence) into various forms (e.g., ABA, ABBA, canon).

0222D36DA1F94BD78FB7ED293FB8CFC4.description: Use the concept web as a guide for movement exploration and improvisation.

43F03138C5C64F4891B7867679DAC554.description: Collaborate on the creation of a concept web of dance elements and possible movements related to an inquiry question.

CFD5669871784EA98E97DF78659003F5.description: Investigate and use choreographic forms (e.g., theme and variations, canon).

EA6EF80BAD5247C38E3EAE602AC2F639.description: Contribute to the creation of a plan to document the inquiry and creative process (e.g., video, photography, blog, or digital diary).

994CFF13BD994B25A80B8F994997D792.description: Reflect on how movement, dance elements, and principles of composition can be organized to convey meaning in dance (e.g., What message or ideas does our dance communicate about current attitudes towards poverty or racism?).

71D640EB6823446CBA7023366DD6555B.description: Investigate how a single idea can be developed in many ways and directions (e.g., How many different ways can we represent through movement a feeling of hopelessness or anger about this injustice?).

FD85CEFEF8BD425FBDFF21EB2FB1F570.description: Use inquiry in dance to express student perspectives on social issues (e.g., poverty, racism, homophobia, sustainability): Generate key questions to guide inquiry in dance (e.g., How could we represent through dance the devastating effects of poverty or racism?), Summarize and focus knowledge of topic to determine information needs, Generate additional relevant questions for deeper exploration, Use the Internet and other relevant sources (e.g., print, digital, community) to research and gather ideas for dance-making. • Adjust inquiry and research strategies to accommodate changing perspectives, Use the dance-making process to explore the central questions and ideas (e.g., How could we show through movement the effects of a hurtful comment?), Expand on dance and movement ideas in reflective records such as journals, blogs, and video or audio recordings, Keep a record of dance phrases using invented and/or traditional notation symbols, and video where possible, to explore, record, and reconstruct movements and Reflect, analyze, and make connections between the original topic or inquiry question and subsequent dance explorations.

9EE8A3B498E842B09AA840CD71D3ED49.description: Create dance compositions that express ideas and student perspectives on social issues (e.g., poverty, racism, homophobia, sustainability, gangs).

36A8EFBB019B424D860154D6FC1AAE7F.description: Creative/Productive (CP) - Children will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music, and visual art.
